charts.name: Pie Chart
charts.subtitle: Basic breakdown
use: Fewer than 6 slices
Summing to a meaningful total (e.g., 100%)
Exact comparison between slices is not critical
avoid: All slices are similar size (hard to compare)

charts.name: Treemap
charts.subtitle: Many categories
use: More than ~10 categories
Hierarchical data (nested structure)
Space efficiency is important
avoid: You need precise comparisons of each segment’s size

charts.name: Stacked Bar Chart
charts.subtitle: Ranked parts
use: Showing both total size and composition
You have 3–8 categories to stack
Order of stacks follows a logical sequence
avoid: Need to compare non-baseline segments accurately
Data has many small or thin segments

charts.name: 100% Stacked Bar
charts.subtitle: Simple share
use: Proportions within each bar must total exactly 100%
Tracking part-to-whole across a few categories
avoid: You need to see absolute values and not just percentages

charts.name: Treemap
charts.subtitle: Basic hierarchy
notes: Particularly useful for multiple levels of nested data

charts.name: Sunburst Chart (If supported)
charts.subtitle: Drill-down
notes: Keep it simple—same rationale as treemap for hierarchical data

charts.name: Stacked Bar (with grouping)
charts.subtitle: Simple levels
notes: Useful if you have limited layers and want quick comparisons

charts.name: 100% Stacked Column Chart
charts.subtitle: Changing shares
use: Tracking how proportions change over time
Total always represents 100%

charts.name: Stacked Column Chart
charts.subtitle: Absolute changes
use: Both the total and the breakdown of the total matter over periods
Fewer than ~8 segments in each stack

charts.name: Stacked Area Chart
charts.subtitle: Multiple periods
use: Emphasizing the magnitude (volume) over time
Seeing how parts contribute to a total trend
avoid: Many frequent crossovers between categories (fills get confusing)
Very spiky data that makes the area shape awkward

charts.name: Bar Chart (Vertical or Horizontal)
charts.subtitle: Simple comparison
use: Comparing discrete categories or ranked items
Emphasizing the size differences clearly
avoid: Over 20–30 categories (may need a different approach or scrolling)

charts.name: Clustered (Grouped) Bar Chart
charts.subtitle: Multiple measures
use: Comparing subgroups within main categories
Number of groups and subgroups is manageable (avoid overload)

charts.name: Column Chart
charts.subtitle: Few items
notes: Similar to bar chart but vertical—useful for small sets
Don’t clutter with too many data points

charts.name: Horizontal Bar Chart
charts.subtitle: Many items
notes: Easier to read long category labels

charts.name: Sorted Bar Chart
charts.subtitle: Ranked items
notes: Sort bars ascending or descending for quick scanning of top/bottom performers

charts.name: Line Chart
charts.subtitle: Continuous trend
use: Showing a trend or rate of change over many data points
Data is continuous (makes sense to interpolate between points)
avoid: Exact individual values matter more than the trend shape

charts.name: Column Chart
charts.subtitle: Periodic comparison
use: Emphasizing discrete values at intervals (months, quarters)
Fewer than ~20 data points
avoid: Needing to show a smooth trend or a large number of data points

charts.name: Multi-Line Chart
charts.subtitle: Multiple trends
use: Comparing multiple series over time
Overlapping lines remain distinct enough to see relationships

charts.name: Area Chart
charts.subtitle: Cumulative
use: Emphasizing total volume or magnitude over time
Smooth, gradual changes
avoid: Data is extremely volatile with large spikes/dips

charts.name: Bar Chart with Reference Line
charts.subtitle: Single reference
notes: Good for comparing each category to a benchmark or target

charts.name: Bullet Chart
charts.subtitle: Multiple references
notes: Can show performance against multiple thresholds (e.g., target, stretch goal)

charts.name: Gauge Chart
charts.subtitle: Progress to goal
use: Showing a single metric’s progress toward 100% (or a target)

charts.name: KPI Card
charts.subtitle: Simple status
notes: Keep text and callout clean to highlight one big metric or status

charts.name: Scatter Plot
charts.subtitle: Two variables
use: Checking correlation or spotting outliers between two numeric variables
Large datasets where density or cluster patterns are important

charts.name: Matrix (or advanced table)
charts.subtitle: Multiple variables
notes: Compare multiple numeric variables in a grid
Use color or symbols to indicate correlations

charts.name: Bubble Chart
charts.subtitle: With size
use: Adding a third numeric variable (bubble size)
Looking for patterns with an extra dimension

charts.name: Heatmap
charts.subtitle: Category pairs
use: Visualizing intensity/frequency across two categorical dimensions
Spotting patterns, clusters, or anomalies via color
avoid: Precise numeric comparison is critical—heatmaps are more about trends

charts.name: Matrix
charts.subtitle: Basic correlation
notes: Multiple variables with color-coded correlation values

charts.name: Table with conditional formatting
charts.subtitle: Simple mapping
notes: For small data sets where exact numbers must remain visible

charts.name: Multi-Line Chart
charts.subtitle: Multiple series
notes: Already covered above; emphasizes concurrent trends

charts.name: Combo Chart (Line + Column)
charts.subtitle: Combined trends
use: Two related metrics share a time axis but differ in how they should be visualized
Need to highlight a primary (column) vs. secondary (line) metric

charts.name: Small Multiples
charts.subtitle: Period comparison
notes: Comparing the same measure across different small charts helps isolate patterns
